elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig1">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Views of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. (a) ORTEP view (30% thermal ellipsoids) showing the coordination environment of Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> (symmetry operation for A: −<ce:italic>x,</ce:italic>
<ce:italic>y,</ce:italic> −<ce:italic>z</ce:italic> + 1/2). (b) (left) Perspective view of the layered H-bonding pattern. (right) Schematic representation of the 3-fold interpenetrating (4,4) layers. (c) (left) 3-D network directed by interlayer aromatic stacking interactions (indicated as red broken lines). (right) Space-filling diagram of the 3-fold interpenetrating 3-D framework.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  Views of 1. (a) ORTEP view (30% thermal ellipsoids) showing the coordination environment of ZnII (symmetry operation for A: -x, y, -z + 1/2). (b) (left) Perspective view of the layered H-bonding pattern. (right) Schematic representation of the 3-fold interpenetrating (4,4) layers. (c) (left) 3-D network directed by interlayer aromatic stacking interactions (indicated as red broken lines). (right) Space-filling diagram of the 3-fold interpenetrating 3-D framework.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig2">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Views of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. (a) ORTEP view (30% thermal ellipsoids) showing the coordination environment of Cd<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> (symmetry operation for A: −<ce:italic>x,</ce:italic> −<ce:italic>y</ce:italic> + 2<ce:italic>,</ce:italic> −<ce:italic>z</ce:italic>). (b) Perspective view of the layered network <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> O–H<mml:math altimg="si13.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mo>⋯</mml:mo>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:math>O interactions between the mononuclear coordination motifs (the 3-bpo ligands are omitted for clarity). (c) 3-D supramolecular lattice <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> additional interlayer O–H<mml:math altimg="si14.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mo>⋯</mml:mo>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:math>N interactions.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 2  Views of 2. (a) ORTEP view (30% thermal ellipsoids) showing the coordination environment of CdII (symmetry operation for A: -x, -y + 2, -z). (b) Perspective view of the layered network via O-H  ⋯  O interactions between the mononuclear coordination motifs (the 3-bpo ligands are omitted for clarity). (c) 3-D supramolecular lattice via additional interlayer O-H  ⋯  N interactions.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig3">
<ce:label>Fig. 3</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Views of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. (a) ORTEP view (30% thermal ellipsoids) showing the coordination environment of Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> (symmetry operation for A: −<ce:italic>x</ce:italic> + 1<ce:italic>,</ce:italic> −<ce:italic>y</ce:italic> + 1<ce:italic>,</ce:italic> −<ce:italic>z</ce:italic> + 1). (b) Perspective view of the 1-D coordination chain showing the O–H<mml:math altimg="si15.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mo>⋯</mml:mo>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:math>O bonds (the 3-bpo ligands are omitted for clarity). (c) 2-D supramolecular layer directed by interchain aromatic stacking interactions (indicated as green broken lines). (d) 3-D supramolecular network <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> additional interlayer aromatic stacking interactions (indicated as red broken lines) (For interpretation to the references of color in this figure legend the reader is referred to the web version of the article).</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr3"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Fig. 3  Views of 3. (a) ORTEP view (30% thermal ellipsoids) showing the coordination environment of ZnII (symmetry operation for A: -x + 1, -y + 1, -z + 1). (b) Perspective view of the 1-D coordination chain showing the O-H  ⋯  O bonds (the 3-bpo ligands are omitted for clarity). (c) 2-D supramolecular layer directed by interchain aromatic stacking interactions (indicated as green broken lines). (d) 3-D supramolecular network via additional interlayer aromatic stacking interactions (indicated as red broken lines) (For interpretation to the references of color in this figure legend the reader is referred to the web version of the article).

elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

This work reports a series of ZnII, CdII, CoII, and PbII complexes with Br n -terephthalic acid (n =1 or 4) and a versatile bent dipyridyl tecton, which display diversiform coordination motifs and metallosupramolecular architectures that are regulated by substituent effect of the ligands as well as metal ions.

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">This work presents a series of Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>, Cd<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>, Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>, and Pb<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> supramolecular complexes assembled from a bent dipyridyl derivative 2,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole (3-bpo) and different dicarboxyl co-ligands 2-bromoterephthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BTA) and tetrabromoterephthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>TBTA). All products have been prepared under similar conditions and characterized by IR, microanalysis, and TG–DTA techniques. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction indicates that these complexes display mononuclear, 1-D, and 2-D coordination motifs, and diverse higher-dimensional extended networks are further constructed <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> additional secondary interactions such as H-bonding and aromatic stacking. Notably, <ce:italic>in situ</ce:italic> hydrolysis reaction of 3-bpo is observed in the Pb<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> complex with H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>TBTA, affording another dipyridyl-type ligand <ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>′-bis(3-picolinoyl)hydrazine (3-bph). These results evidently reveal the significant substituent effect of terephthalic acid in structural direction of these metallosupramolecular systems that are also regulated by the selection of metal ions.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

This work presents a series of ZnII, CdII, CoII, and PbII supramolecular complexes assembled from a bent dipyridyl derivative 2,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole (3-bpo) and different dicarboxyl co-ligands 2-bromoterephthalic acid (H2BTA) and tetrabromoterephthalic acid (H2TBTA). All products have been prepared under similar conditions and characterized by IR, microanalysis, and TG-DTA techniques. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction indicates that these complexes display mononuclear, 1-D, and 2-D coordination motifs, and diverse higher-dimensional extended networks are further constructed via additional secondary interactions such as H-bonding and aromatic stacking. Notably, in situ hydrolysis reaction of 3-bpo is observed in the PbII complex with H2TBTA, affording another dipyridyl-type ligand N,N'-bis(3-picolinoyl)hydrazine (3-bph). These results evidently reveal the significant substituent effect of terephthalic acid in structural direction of these metallosupramolecular systems that are also regulated by the selection of metal ions.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The flourishing realm of crystal engineering, which focuses on the successful achievement of desired crystalline solids from pre-designed bridging ligands and metal ions, has provided a useful and effective synthetic strategy for the construction of functional materials with established and potential applications . At present, it has been extensively realized that the deliberate selection and utilization of organic tectons plays a profound role in such metallosupramolecular assemblies . In this regard, building components involving pyridyl and/or carboxylate functional groups (for example, 4,4′-bipyridyl and terephthalic acid) have been confirmed to be the most reliable candidates for structural assembly of new coordination solids with interesting network architectures and physicochemical properties .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The flourishing realm of crystal engineering, which focuses on the successful achievement of desired crystalline solids from pre-designed bridging ligands and metal ions, has provided a useful and effective synthetic strategy for the construction of functional materials with established and potential applications . At present, it has been extensively realized that the deliberate selection and utilization of organic tectons plays a profound role in such metallosupramolecular assemblies . In this regard, building components involving pyridyl and/or carboxylate functional groups (for example, 4,4'-bipyridyl and terephthalic acid) have been confirmed to be the most reliable candidates for structural assembly of new coordination solids with interesting network architectures and physicochemical properties .

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">In this context, our previous studies on a modified dipyridyl ligand with the oxadiazole spacer, namely 2,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole (3-bpo), have revealed that such a building block may show three typical conformations (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="cht1"></ce:float-anchor>), various coordination modes, and potential capability for participating in secondary interactions, which thus result in multifarious metallosupramolecular systems <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> coordinative and other noncovalent contacts . As for the Br-substituted terephthalic acid, 2-bromoterephthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BTA) has been utilized to synthesize reticular porous metal–organic frameworks with good capacity for gas adsorption . And very recently, another related analogous compound, tetrabromoterephthalic acid (H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>TBTA), has also been employed to construct novel coordination networks , in which the Br-substituents impose a significant steric effect on the formation of such supramolecular architectures. In this contribution, we will present a series of Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>, Cd<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>, Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>, and Pb<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> mixed-ligand complexes based on H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BTA or H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>TBTA (see ) incorporated with 3-bpo as the building blocks, aiming to explore the intrinsic steric and electronic effect of the Br-substituent of terephthalic acid on the structural direction of these coordination solids.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this context, our previous studies on a modified dipyridyl ligand with the oxadiazole spacer, namely 2,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole (3-bpo), have revealed that such a building block may show three typical conformations (see  ), various coordination modes, and potential capability for participating in secondary interactions, which thus result in multifarious metallosupramolecular systems via coordinative and other noncovalent contacts . As for the Br-substituted terephthalic acid, 2-bromoterephthalic acid (H2BTA) has been utilized to synthesize reticular porous metal-organic frameworks with good capacity for gas adsorption . And very recently, another related analogous compound, tetrabromoterephthalic acid (H2TBTA), has also been employed to construct novel coordination networks , in which the Br-substituents impose a significant steric effect on the formation of such supramolecular architectures. In this contribution, we will present a series of ZnII, CdII, CoII, and PbII mixed-ligand complexes based on H2BTA or H2TBTA (see ) incorporated with 3-bpo as the building blocks, aiming to explore the intrinsic steric and electronic effect of the Br-substituent of terephthalic acid on the structural direction of these coordination solids.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Materials and general methods</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">All reagents and solvents were commercially available and used as received. Fourier transform (FT) IR spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded on an AVATAR-370 (Nicolet) spectrometer. Elemental analyses were carried out on a CE-440 (Leemanlabs) analyzer. Thermogravimetric (TG) and differential thermal analysis (DTA) experiments were performed in the temperature range of 25–700<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C on a Rigaku standard TG-DTA analyzer under nitrogen atmosphere at a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C/min with an empty Al<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> crucible as the reference.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and general methods

All reagents and solvents were commercially available and used as received. Fourier transform (FT) IR spectra (KBr pellets) were recorded on an AVATAR-370 (Nicolet) spectrometer. Elemental analyses were carried out on a CE-440 (Leemanlabs) analyzer. Thermogravimetric (TG) and differential thermal analysis (DTA) experiments were performed in the temperature range of 25-700°C on a Rigaku standard TG-DTA analyzer under nitrogen atmosphere at a heating rate of 10°C/min with an empty Al2O3 crucible as the reference.

Upon evaporation of the solvents, colorless block crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained after ca. 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>week in 51% yield (26.0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mg, based on H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BTA). <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">40</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>ZnN<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>Br<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>: C, 47.11; H, 2.57; N, 10.99. elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of complexes 1-6 

[Zn(HBTA)2(3-bpo)2](H2O) (1)

A mixture of H2BTA (24.5mg, 0.1mmol) and 3-bpo (22.4mg, 0.1mmol) was dissolved in DMF/H2O (10mL, v/v =1/1) under stirring, which was placed at the bottom of a straight glass tube. Then, a CH3OH solution (10mL) of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (29.7mg, 0.1mmol) was carefully layered onto it. Upon evaporation of the solvents, colorless block crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained after ca. 1week in 51% yield (26.0mg, based on H2BTA). Anal. Calc. for C40H26ZnN8O11Br2: C, 47.11; H, 2.57; N, 10.99. Found: C, 46.89; H, 2.71; N, 11.12%. IR (cm-1): 3495bs, 1716m, 1623vs, 1549w, 1468m, 1366s, 1296s, 1239s, 1092m, 1044s, 813m, 772w, 726w, 688w, 648w, 536m.

Found: C, 41.89; H, 3.34; N, 10.01%. IR (cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3425bs, 1641vs, 1578vs, 1466m, 1397s, 1328w, 1245w, 1094m, 1047m, 979w, 781m, 693m, 587w, 514w.</ce:para>

[Cd(HBTA)2(3-bpo)2(H2O)2](H2O)3 (2)

The same synthetic method as that for 1 was used except that Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O was replaced by Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (30.8mg, 0.1mmol), producing colorless block crystals of 2 after ca. 1week in 50% yield (28.5mg, based on H2BTA). Anal. Calc. for C40H34CdN8O15Br2: C, 42.18; H, 3.01; N, 9.84. Found: C, 41.89; H, 3.34; N, 10.01%. IR (cm-1): 3425bs, 1641vs, 1578vs, 1466m, 1397s, 1328w, 1245w, 1094m, 1047m, 979w, 781m, 693m, 587w, 514w.

<ce:section-title>X-ray crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> were collected on a Bruker Apex II CCD diffractometer at 296(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>K with Mo Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å). There was no evidence of crystal decay during data collection. Semi-empirical absorption corrections were applied using <ce:small-caps>sadabs</ce:small-caps> and the program <ce:small-caps>saint</ce:small-caps> was used for integration of the diffraction profiles . The structures were solved by direct methods using the <ce:small-caps>shelxs</ce:small-caps> program of the <ce:small-caps>shelxtl</ce:small-caps> package and refined with <ce:small-caps>shelxl</ce:small-caps>
. The final refinement was performed by full-matrix least-squares methods on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup> with anisotropic thermal parameters for all non-H atoms. In general, hydrogen atoms attached to carbon were generated geometrically and those of oxygen (carboxyl or water) were first located in difference Fourier syntheses and then treated as riding. Isotropic displacement parameters of hydrogen were derived from their parent atoms. Notably, hydrogen atoms of the lattice water molecules of O6 (for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and O8 (for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) were not located. In the structure of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, the lattice water is disordered over two positions (O5 and O5’) with the partial site-occupancies of 0.73 and 0.27, respectively, and the affiliated hydrogen atoms were also not determined. A summary of the crystallographic details of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold> are shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl1"></ce:float-anchor>. Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in  and the hydrogen-bonding geometries are given in .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data for 1-6 were collected on a Bruker Apex II CCD diffractometer at 296(2)K with Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å). There was no evidence of crystal decay during data collection. Semi-empirical absorption corrections were applied using sadabs and the program saint was used for integration of the diffraction profiles . The structures were solved by direct methods using the shelxs program of the shelxtl package and refined with shelxl . The final refinement was performed by full-matrix least-squares methods on F 2 with anisotropic thermal parameters for all non-H atoms. In general, hydrogen atoms attached to carbon were generated geometrically and those of oxygen (carboxyl or water) were first located in difference Fourier syntheses and then treated as riding. Isotropic displacement parameters of hydrogen were derived from their parent atoms. Notably, hydrogen atoms of the lattice water molecules of O6 (for 1) and O8 (for 2) were not located. In the structure of 4, the lattice water is disordered over two positions (O5 and O5') with the partial site-occupancies of 0.73 and 0.27, respectively, and the affiliated hydrogen atoms were also not determined. A summary of the crystallographic details of 1-6 are shown in  . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in  and the hydrogen-bonding geometries are given in .

<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Synthesis and general characterization</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">All complexes were synthesised by layer-separation diffusion of the DMF/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O solution of mixed ligands and the corresponding CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH solution of metal salt at ambient condition, which will facilitate the slow crystallization of X-ray quality single crystals. In each synthetic case, the equivalent metal/dicarboxyl/dipyridyl ratio was utilized for the starting materials. However, the products were found to have the stoichiometric ratios of 1:2:2 for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, 1:1:2 for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, and 1:1:1 for <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>. Notably, the dicarboxyl ligand H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BTA takes the mono-deprotonated form (HBTA) in the resulting complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, whereas H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>TBTA is completely deprotonated in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>. Interestingly, <ce:italic>in situ</ce:italic> hydrolysis reaction of 3-bpo occurs during preparation of the Pb<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> complex <ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, which also represents the first coordination species involving the 3-bph ligand. A related example has been observed in the hydrothermal cocrystallization of 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole (4-bpo) with suberic acid , which leads to the formation of a binary cocrystal formulated as [suberic acid]·[4-bph] (4-bph<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>
<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>,<ce:italic>N</ce:italic>′-bis(4-picolinoyl)hydrazine).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Synthesis and general characterization

All complexes were synthesised by layer-separation diffusion of the DMF/H2O solution of mixed ligands and the corresponding CH3OH solution of metal salt at ambient condition, which will facilitate the slow crystallization of X-ray quality single crystals. In each synthetic case, the equivalent metal/dicarboxyl/dipyridyl ratio was utilized for the starting materials. However, the products were found to have the stoichiometric ratios of 1:2:2 for 1 and 2, 1:1:2 for 3-5, and 1:1:1 for 6. Notably, the dicarboxyl ligand H2BTA takes the mono-deprotonated form (HBTA) in the resulting complexes 1 and 2, whereas H2TBTA is completely deprotonated in 3-6. Interestingly, in situ hydrolysis reaction of 3-bpo occurs during preparation of the PbII complex 6, which also represents the first coordination species involving the 3-bph ligand. A related example has been observed in the hydrothermal cocrystallization of 2,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole (4-bpo) with suberic acid , which leads to the formation of a binary cocrystal formulated as [suberic acid]⋅[4-bph] (4-bph= N,N'-bis(4-picolinoyl)hydrazine).

elements.clean_text:
Structural analysis of 1-6 

[Zn(HBTA)2(3-bpo)2](H2O) (1)

In complex 1, each ZnII ion is located at a 2-fold axis and takes a tetrahedral coordination geometry provided by two carboxylate oxygen donors from a pair of HBTA anions and two pyridyl nitrogen atoms from a pair of 3-bpo ligands (see  a). Weak Zn1  ⋯  O2 interaction is also found with the distance of 2.876(4)Å. As for 2-bromoterephthalic acid, only one carboxyl group thereof is deprotonated and involved in metal coordination. Interestingly, each 3-bpo adopts the unusual cisoid-II conformation and the monodentate ligation mode, which has not been observed in the reported complexes . In this way, a mononuclear coordination motif is formed (see a). As expected, the free carboxyl group of HBTA is hydrogen bonded to the uncoordinated 3-pyridyl group of 3-bpo and thus, each mononuclear molecule is linked to four adjacent ones via such O4-H4  ⋯  N4 interactions to constitute a 2-D (4,4) layer with large rhombic grids, in which the nearest Zn  ⋯  Zn separation is 20.790Å (see b left). Three such symmetry-related corrugated layers are entangled in a parallel fashion to result in a 3-fold interpenetrating architecture (see b right). Moreover, the twisty nature of these layers facilitates the recognition sites for aromatic stacking  between the phenyl group in HBTA and uncoordinated pyridyl ring in 3-bpo, with the centroid-to-centroid distance and the dihedral angle of ca. 3.6Å and 4.4°, respectively. As a result, the adjacent 2-D hydrogen-bonding layers are further combined via π-π stacking interactions (see c left) to afford a 3-D supramolecular framework of 3-fold interpenetration (see c right).

elements.clean_text:
[Cd(HBTA)2(3-bpo)2(H2O)2](H2O)3. (2)

Each half-occupied CdII ion in 2 lying on a symmetric center, is six-coordinated by two pyridyl nitrogen donors as well as four oxygen atoms from two carboxylate groups and two water molecules to furnish an octahedral sphere (see  a). A mononuclear coordination motif, which is similar to that in 1, is also generated in this case. Differently, the incorporation of aqua ligands around the coordination sphere of CdII leads to the formation of O6-H6B  ⋯  O4 and O6-H6A  ⋯  O3 hydrogen bonds with the free oxygen atoms of carboxyl and carboxylate, and thus, a 2-D supramolecular layer (see b) is constructed along the bc plane with the adjacent Cd  ⋯  Cd separation of 11.576Å. Furthermore, the carboxyl group of HBTA is also hydrogen bonded to the uncoordinated pyridyl segment of 3-bpo and such O5-H5  ⋯  N4 interactions extend the 2-D layers into a 3-D network (see c). In addition, hydrogen-boning interactions are observed between the lattice water molecule of O7 and the lattice water of O8 as well as the carboxylate group (see  for details), which may stabilize this 3-D framework. Very small interspace is found in this lattice with a volume of 48.9Å3 (2.1% of the unit cell volume).

<ce:section-title>{[M(TBTA)(3-bpo)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (M<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, Cd<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>4</ce:bold>, and Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> for <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that complexes <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold> are isostructural, hence only the crystal structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> will be discussed in detail here. Each Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion in <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is located at an inversion center and takes a similar MN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> octahedral sphere to that in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>a). Notably, the 3-bpo ligand in this structure adopts the <ce:italic>transoid</ce:italic> conformation and unidentate coordination, and only two similar examples have been found in the 23 known metal complexes with 3-bpo . As a result, the adjacent Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ions are connected by the TBTA dianionic bridges to afford a 1-D linear chain along [0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>0<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1] with the Zn<mml:math altimg="si8.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mo>⋯</mml:mo>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:math>Zn distance of 11.533<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å (see b), which is also decorated by 3-bpo at both sides to form a fishbone-like motif (see c). Each water ligand of O4 is hydrogen bonded (see b) to the adjacent carboxylate within the chain (O4–H4A<mml:math altimg="si9.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mo>⋯</mml:mo>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:math>O2) and the lattice water molecule around the chain (O4–H4B<mml:math altimg="si10.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mo>⋯</mml:mo>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:math>O5, see  for details). These 1-D polymeric motifs are arranged in an interdigitated fashion, which makes the interchain aromatic stacking available to direct a layered network (see c). The centroid-to-centroid distance between the uncoordinated pyridyl group and phenyl ring is ca. 3.6<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å with the dihedral angle of 5.2°. Further investigation of the crystal packing demonstrates that aromatic stacking interactions are also present between these 2-D patterns, constructing the final 3-D supramolecular lattice (see d). The centroid-to-centroid distance and the dihedral angle between the uncoordinated pyridyl and oxadiazole rings are ca. 3.8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and 15.4°, respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
{[M(TBTA)(3-bpo)2(H2O)2](H2O)2} n  (M=ZnII for 3, CdII for 4, and CoII for 5)

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction reveals that complexes 3-5 are isostructural, hence only the crystal structure of 3 will be discussed in detail here. Each ZnII ion in 3 is located at an inversion center and takes a similar MN2O4 octahedral sphere to that in 2 (see  a). Notably, the 3-bpo ligand in this structure adopts the transoid conformation and unidentate coordination, and only two similar examples have been found in the 23 known metal complexes with 3-bpo . As a result, the adjacent ZnII ions are connected by the TBTA dianionic bridges to afford a 1-D linear chain along [001] with the Zn  ⋯  Zn distance of 11.533Å (see b), which is also decorated by 3-bpo at both sides to form a fishbone-like motif (see c). Each water ligand of O4 is hydrogen bonded (see b) to the adjacent carboxylate within the chain (O4-H4A  ⋯  O2) and the lattice water molecule around the chain (O4-H4B  ⋯  O5, see  for details). These 1-D polymeric motifs are arranged in an interdigitated fashion, which makes the interchain aromatic stacking available to direct a layered network (see c). The centroid-to-centroid distance between the uncoordinated pyridyl group and phenyl ring is ca. 3.6Å with the dihedral angle of 5.2°. Further investigation of the crystal packing demonstrates that aromatic stacking interactions are also present between these 2-D patterns, constructing the final 3-D supramolecular lattice (see d). The centroid-to-centroid distance and the dihedral angle between the uncoordinated pyridyl and oxadiazole rings are ca. 3.8Å and 15.4°, respectively.

elements.clean_text:
[Pb(TBTA)(3-bph)] n  (6)

When the post-transition metal ion PbII is used in the assembled process, a 2-D coordination polymer is obtained with the observation of in situ hydrolysis of the 3-bpo ligand. In this structure, the PbII center with 2-fold symmetry shows a distorted octahedral sphere, which is defined by four oxygen atoms from a pair of carboxylate groups and two pyridyl nitrogen donors (see  a). Both the transoid 3-bph ligands and TBTA dianions serve as bidentate spacers to link the PbII ions into a (4,4) coordination layer (see b), in which the Pb  ⋯  Pb separations bridged by 3-bph and TBTA are 13.856 and 11.713Å, respectively. Such crooked layers align in a parallel mode along [010], which are further connected by the interlayer N2-H2  ⋯  O1 bonds (see ) to generate a 3-D supramolecular framework (see c).

</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>6</ce:bold>, a variety of metallosupramolecular architectures with different propagating and packing fashions are constructed, which should be mainly attributed to substituent effect of the dicarboxyl ligand as well as metal ion. It is beneficial to compare their structural features (see 
<ce:float-anchor refid="tbl2"></ce:float-anchor>) for further summarizing the role of these impact factors on the assembled processes.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structural diversity and comparison of 1-6 

In complexes 1-6, a variety of metallosupramolecular architectures with different propagating and packing fashions are constructed, which should be mainly attributed to substituent effect of the dicarboxyl ligand as well as metal ion. It is beneficial to compare their structural features (see  ) for further summarizing the role of these impact factors on the assembled processes.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Clearly, although the Br-substituted group is normally regarded as the uncoordinated site, the introduction of different amounts of –Br on the backbone of terephthalic acid (one for H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BTA and four for H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>TBTA) does significantly affect the deprotonated degree and binding mode of the ligands in their metal complexes. Generally, the Br-substituent can affect the acidity of terephthalic acid in two manners. On the one hand, as an electron-withdrawing group, the Br-substituent can increase the acidity of –COOH by changing its electron density and stabilizing the negatively charged –COO<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> counterpart from the viewpoint of field effect, and this effect will decrease when the distance between the –Br and –COOH groups is increased. On the other hand, due to the steric effect, the –COOH group is forced out of the phenyl plane by the <ce:italic>ortho</ce:italic>-Br group to make a nearly perpendicular disposition, and then increases its acidity by adjusting the resonance effect. As a result, by combination of such two types of effects, the acidity of <ce:italic>ortho</ce:italic>-COOH should be stronger than that of the <ce:italic>meta</ce:italic>-COOH in the Br-substituted aromatic dicarboxyl compounds. Accordingly, the two –COOH groups in H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>BTA, locating at the <ce:italic>ortho</ce:italic>- and <ce:italic>meta</ce:italic>-positions to –Br, display different acidity and thus the deprotonated behavior as well as the deviation degree to the Br-substituted phenyl plane in complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> (see  for details). And consequently, the –COOH groups of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>TBTA in the resulting complexes uniformly show the carboxylate form and are nearly perpendicular to the Br<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-substituted phenyl plane (see ).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Clearly, although the Br-substituted group is normally regarded as the uncoordinated site, the introduction of different amounts of -Br on the backbone of terephthalic acid (one for H2BTA and four for H2TBTA) does significantly affect the deprotonated degree and binding mode of the ligands in their metal complexes. Generally, the Br-substituent can affect the acidity of terephthalic acid in two manners. On the one hand, as an electron-withdrawing group, the Br-substituent can increase the acidity of -COOH by changing its electron density and stabilizing the negatively charged -COO- counterpart from the viewpoint of field effect, and this effect will decrease when the distance between the -Br and -COOH groups is increased. On the other hand, due to the steric effect, the -COOH group is forced out of the phenyl plane by the ortho-Br group to make a nearly perpendicular disposition, and then increases its acidity by adjusting the resonance effect. As a result, by combination of such two types of effects, the acidity of ortho-COOH should be stronger than that of the meta-COOH in the Br-substituted aromatic dicarboxyl compounds. Accordingly, the two -COOH groups in H2BTA, locating at the ortho- and meta-positions to -Br, display different acidity and thus the deprotonated behavior as well as the deviation degree to the Br-substituted phenyl plane in complexes 1 and 2 (see  for details). And consequently, the -COOH groups of H2TBTA in the resulting complexes uniformly show the carboxylate form and are nearly perpendicular to the Br4-substituted phenyl plane (see ).

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The nature of metal ion is also a crucial factor in directing the structural assemblage of these complexes. For example, although both the Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> and Cd<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> have the mononuclear coordination motifs with similar binding modes of the ligands, distinct 3-D supramolecular lattices are formed <ce:italic>via</ce:italic> secondary interactions, probably due to their different coordination tendency (the incorporation of additional aqua ligands in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>). As far as the Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>, Cd<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>, and Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> complexes <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, the isostructural 1-D coordination arrays should be ascribed to a ligand-directed assembly, while the presence of Pb<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> ion induces the <ce:italic>in situ</ce:italic> hydrolysis of 3-bpo to afford a 2-D coordination network based on TBTA and 3-bph linkers.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The nature of metal ion is also a crucial factor in directing the structural assemblage of these complexes. For example, although both the ZnII and CdII complexes 1 and 2 have the mononuclear coordination motifs with similar binding modes of the ligands, distinct 3-D supramolecular lattices are formed via secondary interactions, probably due to their different coordination tendency (the incorporation of additional aqua ligands in 2). As far as the ZnII, CdII, and CoII complexes 3-5, the isostructural 1-D coordination arrays should be ascribed to a ligand-directed assembly, while the presence of PbII ion induces the in situ hydrolysis of 3-bpo to afford a 2-D coordination network based on TBTA and 3-bph linkers.

<ce:section-title>Thermal stability of <ce:bold>1–6</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">All complexes are air stable and their thermal stability was explored by TG-DTA technique (see  for TG–DTA curves). The TG curve of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows the first weight loss of 2.23% (calculated: 1.76%) from 90 to 156<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, corresponding to the exclusion of one lattice aqua molecule (an endothermic peak at 130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in DTA). The residual component starts to decompose until heating to 250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, which ends at 616<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C with one endothermic and two exothermic peaks at 263 and 468/543<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in the DTA curve. As for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the first weight loss of 7.95% from 44 to 139<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in the TG curve suggests the release of all lattice and coordination water molecules (calculated: 7.90%). Accordingly, one endothermic peak is observed at 132<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in the DTA curve. Upon further heating to 232<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, a series of weight losses occur, which end at 588<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (one endothermic peak at 288<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and one exothermic peak at 403<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in DTA). The resulting residue holds a weight of 10.96% of the total sample and seems to be CdO (calculated: 11.27%). Complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is thermally stable to 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, where the weight loss occurs and does not end until heating to 700<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Accordingly, one endothermic peak at 223<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and three exothermic peaks at 249, 451, and 668<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C are observed in the DTA curve. The polymeric framework of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> is stable up to 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, and then suffers a series of continuous weight losses that end at 690<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (one endothermic peak at 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and two exothermic peaks at 470/660<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in DTA). With regard to <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, the framework remains intact upon heating to 123<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, followed by a series of weight losses ending at 612<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (two endothermic peaks at 184/276<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and one exothermic peak at 468<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in the DTA curve). The TGA curve of <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> indicates that the coordination network starts to decompose at 178<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C with a sharp weight loss ending at 378<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Correspondingly, one endothermic peak and one exothermic peak are observed at 260 and 320<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in the DTA curve. Further heating of the remaining substance to 700<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C reveals a slow and consecutive weight loss with one exothermic peak appearing at 477<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in DTA.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal stability of 1-6 

All complexes are air stable and their thermal stability was explored by TG-DTA technique (see  for TG-DTA curves). The TG curve of 1 shows the first weight loss of 2.23% (calculated: 1.76%) from 90 to 156°C, corresponding to the exclusion of one lattice aqua molecule (an endothermic peak at 130°C in DTA). The residual component starts to decompose until heating to 250°C, which ends at 616°C with one endothermic and two exothermic peaks at 263 and 468/543°C in the DTA curve. As for 2, the first weight loss of 7.95% from 44 to 139°C in the TG curve suggests the release of all lattice and coordination water molecules (calculated: 7.90%). Accordingly, one endothermic peak is observed at 132°C in the DTA curve. Upon further heating to 232°C, a series of weight losses occur, which end at 588°C (one endothermic peak at 288°C and one exothermic peak at 403°C in DTA). The resulting residue holds a weight of 10.96% of the total sample and seems to be CdO (calculated: 11.27%). Complex 3 is thermally stable to 160°C, where the weight loss occurs and does not end until heating to 700°C. Accordingly, one endothermic peak at 223°C and three exothermic peaks at 249, 451, and 668°C are observed in the DTA curve. The polymeric framework of 4 is stable up to 120°C, and then suffers a series of continuous weight losses that end at 690°C (one endothermic peak at 200°C and two exothermic peaks at 470/660°C in DTA). With regard to 5, the framework remains intact upon heating to 123°C, followed by a series of weight losses ending at 612°C (two endothermic peaks at 184/276°C and one exothermic peak at 468°C in the DTA curve). The TGA curve of 6 indicates that the coordination network starts to decompose at 178°C with a sharp weight loss ending at 378°C. Correspondingly, one endothermic peak and one exothermic peak are observed at 260 and 320°C in the DTA curve. Further heating of the remaining substance to 700°C reveals a slow and consecutive weight loss with one exothermic peak appearing at 477°C in DTA.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In this work, six new Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>, Cd<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>, Co<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup>, and Pb<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> complexes assembled from the building blocks of Br<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>-terephthalic acid and 3-bpo are presented. Their discrete, 1-D, and 2-D coordination motifs are further extended by the secondary interactions to construct diversiform 3-D metallosupramolecular architectures, in which the 3-bpo ligands show unusual <ce:italic>cisoid-</ce:italic>II or <ce:italic>transoid</ce:italic> conformations. Structural diversity of these complexes can be primarily attributed to the significant substituent effect of the Br<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>-terephthalic acid tectons as well as the nature of metal ions. These results promote us to make a further systemic study on the coordination chemistry of halogen-substituent dicarboxyl ligands, which may enrich the scope of crystal engineering for supramolecular hybrid solids.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In this work, six new ZnII, CdII, CoII, and PbII complexes assembled from the building blocks of Br n -terephthalic acid and 3-bpo are presented. Their discrete, 1-D, and 2-D coordination motifs are further extended by the secondary interactions to construct diversiform 3-D metallosupramolecular architectures, in which the 3-bpo ligands show unusual cisoid-II or transoid conformations. Structural diversity of these complexes can be primarily attributed to the significant substituent effect of the Br n -terephthalic acid tectons as well as the nature of metal ions. These results promote us to make a further systemic study on the coordination chemistry of halogen-substituent dicarboxyl ligands, which may enrich the scope of crystal engineering for supramolecular hybrid solids.

Synthesis of complexes 1-6 

[Zn(HBTA)2(3-bpo)2](H2O) (1)

A mixture of H2BTA (24.5mg, 0.1mmol) and 3-bpo (22.4mg, 0.1mmol) was dissolved in DMF/H2O (10mL, v/v =1/1) under stirring, which was placed at the bottom of a straight glass tube. Then, a CH3OH solution (10mL) of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (29.7mg, 0.1mmol) was carefully layered onto it. Upon evaporation of the solvents, colorless block crystals of 1 suitable for X-ray diffraction were obtained after ca. 1week in 51% yield (26.0mg, based on H2BTA). Anal. Calc. for C40H26ZnN8O11Br2: C, 47.11; H, 2.57; N, 10.99. Found: C, 46.89; H, 2.71; N, 11.12%. IR (cm-1): 3495bs, 1716m, 1623vs, 1549w, 1468m, 1366s, 1296s, 1239s, 1092m, 1044s, 813m, 772w, 726w, 688w, 648w, 536m.

[Cd(HBTA)2(3-bpo)2(H2O)2](H2O)3 (2)

The same synthetic method as that for 1 was used except that Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O was replaced by Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (30.8mg, 0.1mmol), producing colorless block crystals of 2 after ca. 1week in 50% yield (28.5mg, based on H2BTA). Anal. Calc. for C40H34CdN8O15Br2: C, 42.18; H, 3.01; N, 9.84. Found: C, 41.89; H, 3.34; N, 10.01%. IR (cm-1): 3425bs, 1641vs, 1578vs, 1466m, 1397s, 1328w, 1245w, 1094m, 1047m, 979w, 781m, 693m, 587w, 514w.

{[Zn(TBTA)(3-bpo)2(H2O)2](H2O)2} n  (3)

The same synthetic method as that for 1 was used except that H2BTA was replaced by H2TBTA (48.2mg, 0.1mmol), giving colorless block crystals of 3 after ca. 1week in 70% yield (37.3mg, based on 3-bpo). Anal. Calc. for C32H24ZnN8O10Br4: C, 36.07; H, 2.27; N, 10.52. Found: C, 36.20; H, 1.99; N, 10.26%. IR (cm-1): 3352bs, 1582vs, 1470m, 1400s, 1320s, 1196w, 1082m, 1031m, 966w, 870w, 802m, 732m, 696s, 624m, 565m, 525w.

{[Cd(TBTA)(3-bpo)2(H2O)2](H2O)2} n  (4)

The same synthetic method as that for 1 was used except that H2BTA and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O were replaced by H2TBTA (48.2mg, 0.1mmol) and Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (30.8mg, 0.1mmol), respectively. Colorless block crystals of 4 were obtained after ca. 1week in 62% yield (34.5mg, based on 3-bpo). Anal. Calc. for C32H24CdN8O10Br4: C, 34.54; H, 2.17; N, 10.07. Found: C, 34.19; H, 2.35; N, 10.24%. IR (cm-1): 3421bs, 1707m, 1596vs, 1462w, 1403m, 1318s, 1241m, 1055s, 782w, 694s, 641w, 561w.

{[Co(TBTA)(3-bpo)2(H2O)2](H2O)2} n  (5)

The same synthetic method as that for 1 was used except that H2BTA and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O were replaced by H2TBTA (48.2mg, 0.1mmol) and Co(OAc)2⋅4H2O (25.0mg, 0.1mmol), respectively. Red block crystals of 5 were obtained after ca. 1week in 66% yield (35.0mg, based on 3-bpo). Anal. Calc. for C32H24CoN8O10Br4: C, 36.29; H, 2.28; N, 10.58. Found: C, 35.92; H, 1.98; N, 10.26%. IR (cm-1): 3359bs, 1578vs, 1471m, 1402s, 1320s, 1195w, 1082m, 1031m, 967w, 877w, 801m, 696s, 628w, 566m.

[Pb(TBTA)(3-bph)] n  (6)

The same synthetic method as that for 1 was used except that H2BTA and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O were replaced by H2TBTA (48.2mg, 0.1mmol) and Pb(OAc)2⋅3H2O (38.0mg, 0.1mmol), respectively. Colorless block crystals of 6 were obtained after ca. 2weeks in 44% yield (40.9mg). Anal. Calc. for C20H10PbN4O6Br4: C, 25.85; H, 1.08; N, 6.03. Found: C, 25.61; H, 1.19; N, 5.87%. IR (cm-1): 3435b, 3082m, 1708m, 1608s, 1378vs, 1316vs, 1242m, 1056m, 832w, 785w, 691m, 567w.

<ce:section-title>Thermal stability of <ce:bold>1–6</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">All complexes are air stable and their thermal stability was explored by TG-DTA technique (see  for TG–DTA curves). The TG curve of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows the first weight loss of 2.23% (calculated: 1.76%) from 90 to 156<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, corresponding to the exclusion of one lattice aqua molecule (an endothermic peak at 130<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in DTA). The residual component starts to decompose until heating to 250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, which ends at 616<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C with one endothermic and two exothermic peaks at 263 and 468/543<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in the DTA curve. As for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the first weight loss of 7.95% from 44 to 139<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in the TG curve suggests the release of all lattice and coordination water molecules (calculated: 7.90%). Accordingly, one endothermic peak is observed at 132<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in the DTA curve. Upon further heating to 232<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, a series of weight losses occur, which end at 588<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (one endothermic peak at 288<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and one exothermic peak at 403<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in DTA). The resulting residue holds a weight of 10.96% of the total sample and seems to be CdO (calculated: 11.27%). Complex <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is thermally stable to 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, where the weight loss occurs and does not end until heating to 700<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Accordingly, one endothermic peak at 223<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and three exothermic peaks at 249, 451, and 668<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C are observed in the DTA curve. The polymeric framework of <ce:bold>4</ce:bold> is stable up to 120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, and then suffers a series of continuous weight losses that end at 690<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (one endothermic peak at 200<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and two exothermic peaks at 470/660<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in DTA). With regard to <ce:bold>5</ce:bold>, the framework remains intact upon heating to 123<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, followed by a series of weight losses ending at 612<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C (two endothermic peaks at 184/276<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C and one exothermic peak at 468<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in the DTA curve). The TGA curve of <ce:bold>6</ce:bold> indicates that the coordination network starts to decompose at 178<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C with a sharp weight loss ending at 378<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Correspondingly, one endothermic peak and one exothermic peak are observed at 260 and 320<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in the DTA curve. Further heating of the remaining substance to 700<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C reveals a slow and consecutive weight loss with one exothermic peak appearing at 477<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in DTA.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Thermal stability of 1-6 

All complexes are air stable and their thermal stability was explored by TG-DTA technique (see  for TG-DTA curves). The TG curve of 1 shows the first weight loss of 2.23% (calculated: 1.76%) from 90 to 156°C, corresponding to the exclusion of one lattice aqua molecule (an endothermic peak at 130°C in DTA). The residual component starts to decompose until heating to 250°C, which ends at 616°C with one endothermic and two exothermic peaks at 263 and 468/543°C in the DTA curve. As for 2, the first weight loss of 7.95% from 44 to 139°C in the TG curve suggests the release of all lattice and coordination water molecules (calculated: 7.90%). Accordingly, one endothermic peak is observed at 132°C in the DTA curve. Upon further heating to 232°C, a series of weight losses occur, which end at 588°C (one endothermic peak at 288°C and one exothermic peak at 403°C in DTA). The resulting residue holds a weight of 10.96% of the total sample and seems to be CdO (calculated: 11.27%). Complex 3 is thermally stable to 160°C, where the weight loss occurs and does not end until heating to 700°C. Accordingly, one endothermic peak at 223°C and three exothermic peaks at 249, 451, and 668°C are observed in the DTA curve. The polymeric framework of 4 is stable up to 120°C, and then suffers a series of continuous weight losses that end at 690°C (one endothermic peak at 200°C and two exothermic peaks at 470/660°C in DTA). With regard to 5, the framework remains intact upon heating to 123°C, followed by a series of weight losses ending at 612°C (two endothermic peaks at 184/276°C and one exothermic peak at 468°C in the DTA curve). The TGA curve of 6 indicates that the coordination network starts to decompose at 178°C with a sharp weight loss ending at 378°C. Correspondingly, one endothermic peak and one exothermic peak are observed at 260 and 320°C in the DTA curve. Further heating of the remaining substance to 700°C reveals a slow and consecutive weight loss with one exothermic peak appearing at 477°C in DTA.

endothermic peak and two exothermic peaks

cln_elements.clean_text:
Table 2. A comparison of the structural features in complexes 1–6.

| Complex | Dicarboxyl | θo- / θm-[^a] | Dipyridyl | Hydrogen-bonding | Aromatic stacking |
|---------|------------|--------------|-----------|------------------|-------------------|
| 1 (Zn<sup>II</sup>) | HBTA (o-COO<sup>–</sup>, m-COOH) | 78.9/7.1 | cisoid-II-3-bpo | O–H⋯N | face-to-face |
| 2 (Cd<sup>II</sup>) | HBTA (o-COO<sup>–</sup>, m-COOH) | 69.4/12.4 | cisoid-II-3-bpo | O–H⋯N/O–H⋯O | not available |
| 3 (Zn<sup>II</sup>) | TBTA (o-COO<sup>–</sup>) | 80.3/--- | transoid-3-bpo | O–H⋯O | face-to-face |
| 4 (Cd<sup>II</sup>) | TBTA (o-COO<sup>–</sup>) | 81.1/--- | transoid-3-bpo | O–H⋯O | face-to-face |
| 5 (Co<sup>II</sup>) | TBTA (o-COO<sup>–</sup>) | 80.7/--- | transoid-3-bpo | O–H⋯O | face-to-face |
| 6 (Pb<sup>II</sup>) | TBTA (o-COO<sup>–</sup>) | 89.7/--- | transoid-3-bph | N–H⋯O | not available |

[^a]: The dihedral angle between the ortho-/meta-carboxylate/carboxyl group and the Br-substituted phenyl plane.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:figure id="fig1">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Views of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. (a) ORTEP view (30% thermal ellipsoids) showing the coordination environment of Zn<ce:sup loc="post">II</ce:sup> (symmetry operation for A: −<ce:italic>x,</ce:italic>
<ce:italic>y,</ce:italic> −<ce:italic>z</ce:italic> + 1/2). (b) (left) Perspective view of the layered H-bonding pattern. (right) Schematic representation of the 3-fold interpenetrating (4,4) layers. (c) (left) 3-D network directed by interlayer aromatic stacking interactions (indicated as red broken lines). (right) Space-filling diagram of the 3-fold interpenetrating 3-D framework.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 1  Views of 1. (a) ORTEP view (30% thermal ellipsoids) showing the coordination environment of ZnII (symmetry operation for A: -x, y, -z + 1/2). (b) (left) Perspective view of the layered H-bonding pattern. (right) Schematic representation of the 3-fold interpenetrating (4,4) layers. (c) (left) 3-D network directed by interlayer aromatic stacking interactions (indicated as red broken lines). (right) Space-filling diagram of the 3-fold interpenetrating 3-D framework.
